taxon_identification.other_info_on_name: [Greek korios , bedbug, and -opsis , resembling, alluding to cypselae of original species]

bio:treatment.discussion: Early leaves of some coreopsises often differ from later leaves on individual plants. In such plants, early (proximal) leaves may be 1–3-pinnately or pedately lobed and 12–25+ cm long with 9–15+ orbiculate to lanceolate, linear, or filiform lobes and contrast markedly with later (distal) leaves 1–3 cm that are undivided or have 3–5+ lanceolate to linear or filiform lobes.

Cultivars (often “doubles” with multiple series of “ray” florets) derived from Coreopsis auriculata, C. grandiflora, C. lanceolata, and C. tinctoria are grown in public and residential gardens and are grown commercially for cut flowers.

references.reference: Jansen, R. K., E. B. Smith, and D. J. Crawford. 1987. A cladistic study of North American Coreopsis (Asteraceae: Heliantheae). Pl. Syst. Evol. 157: 73–84.
Smith, E. B. 1976. A biosystematic survey of Coreopsis in eastern United States and Canada. Sida 6: 123–215.
Smith, E. B. 1984. Biosystematic study and typification of the Californian Coreopsis (Compositae) sections Tuckermannia, Pugiopappus, and Euleptosyne. Sida 10: 276–289.

key_statement.description: Ray florets usually pistillate and fertile, sometimes styliferous and sterile.
Perennials, subshrubs, or shrubs; ray laminae ± elliptic to oblong, broadest at or near middles
Annuals; ray laminae obovate to ± flabellate, broadest distal to middles.
Cypselae of disc florets ciliolate; pappi of 2 lanceolate to subulate scales
Cypselae of disc florets not ciliolate; pappi 0 or coroniform (0.1–0.2 mm)
Leaf blades usually not lobed, rarely with 1–2 auricles at bases (margins dentate); rayflorets 4–5; disc florets 10–15+
Leaf blades sometimes lobed (ultimate margins not dentate); ray florets (5–)8(–13; more in “double” cultivars); disc florets 30–150+.
Disc corolla lobes 5; style-branch apices usually ± penicillate, sometimes short-conic or truncate-mucronate.
Ray laminae ± oblong-elliptic to suborbiculate, broadest at or near middles; paleae usually linear to subulate, often distally dilated
Ray laminae ± cuneate, broadest distal to middles; paleae basally ± lanceolate to linear, distally attenuate (± filiform)
Disc corolla lobes 4; style-branch apices ± truncate.
Leaf blades sometimes with 1–2 lateral lobes; cypselae sometimes winged, wings ± pectinate or toothed
Leaf blades usually 1–2(–3)-pinnately lobed; cypselae sometimes winged, wingsentire
